museScoreManual.page:
Accidentes
Los accidentes pueden ser agregados o cambiados arrastrándolos desde la paleta de accidentes a una nota en la partitura.
Si solamente quiere cambiar el tono de una nota, puede seleccionarla y:
Arriba Aumentar la nota en un semitono.
Abajo Decrementar la nota en un semitono
Ctrl+Arriba Aumentar la nota una octava.
Ctrl+Abajo Decrementar la nota en una octava
MuseScore automáticamente intenta utilizar el accidente apropiado para la nota cambiada. Si no está de acuerdo con esto o quiere agregar un accidente cautelar (accidente editorial), debe arrastrar el accidente manualmente desde la paleta de accidentes. Si nuevamente cambia la nota con las teclas de cursor, el accidente manualmente agregado se perderá.
La función de menú <Notes/Pitch spell> intenta adivinar los accidentes correctos para toda la partitura.

tr.td: Los arpegios son agregados a una nota de un acorde arrastrando un símbolo de arpegio desde la paleta de arpegios.

museScoreManual.page:
Barras de compás
Podemos cambiar las barras de compás arrastrado uno de los símbolos de barra de compás desde la paleta de barras de compás hacia una de las barras de la partitura.
Create grand staff
To extend bar lines over multiple staves double click on a bar line to edit it (see Edit mode).
Click and drag the blue square down to the next staff. All staff bar lines will be updated when you leave edit mode.
See also Measure Operations.

Agrupaciones
Las agrupaciones de notas se van creando de forma automática, pero podemos modificarlas manualmente. Para ello arrastramos el símbolo de agrupación desde la paleta de agrupaciones hacia la nota que queremos modificar. Otra forma de hacerlo es seleccionar primero la nota y después hacer doble clic en el símbolo apropiado de la paleta de agrupaciones.
Iniciar agrupación en la nota.
No finalizar agrupación en la nota.
No agrupar la nota.
Iniciar agrupación de segundo nivel en la nota.
Véase también: Véase también: Agrupaciones entre compases.

Corchetes
Eliminar:
Seleccionar el corchete y pulsar <Del>
Añadir:
Arrastrar un símbolo de corchete desde la paleta de corchetes hacia un espacio en blanco en el primer compás de un sistema.
Cambiar:
Arrastrar un símbolo de corchete desde la paleta de corchetes hacia un corchete de la partitura.
Editar:
Hacer doble clic en un corchete para activar el modo de edición. En el modo de edición se puede modificar la altura de un corchete para expandir arbitrariamente pentagramas de un sistema.

tr.td:
Podemos forzar un salto de página o de línea (salto de sistema) arrastrando un símbolo de salto de página o de línea desde la paleta de saltos hacia un espacio en blanco de la partitura.
El salto ocurrirá después del compás marcado.
Por supuesto, las marcas visibles de los saltos no se imprimen.

museScoreManual.page:
Respiro
Para poner un respiro arrastramos un símbolo de respiro desde la paleta de respiros hacia una nota de la partitura. El símbolo de respiro quedará delante de la nota.
Símbolo de respiro en una partitura:

Nombres de acordes
Los nombres de los acordes pueden ser ingresados luego de seleccionar una nota y apretar <Ctrl+K>. Esto crea un objeto de texto para el acorde seleccionado.
Use <espacio> para ir al siguiente acorde.
<Shift+Espacio> va al acorde anterior.
<Ctrl+Espacio> ingresa un <espacio> en el texto del nombre del acorde.
Los nombres de los acordes pueden ser editados como texto normal.

Claves
Las claves son creadas o cambiadas arrastrándolas desde la paleta de claves a un compás u otra clave.
<F9> Cambia la ventana de paletas.
Cambiar
Arrastre una clave desde la paleta a una clave de la partitura. También es posible arrastrar una clave desde la partitura a otra clave de la partitura, usando<Shift+leftMouseButton+Drag>.
Agregar
Arrastre una clave desde la paleta dentro de una sección vacía de un compás. Esto crea una clave al principio del compás. Si el compás no es el primero del pentagrama, se dibujará más pequeño.
Quitar
Seleccione una clave y presione <Supr>.
Note que al cambiar la no cambia el tono de ninguna nota, sino que son movidas.

Edit Mode Many elements in the score can be edited in <Edit Mode>:
<Double Click>
start <Edit Mode>
<Escape>
end <Edit Mode>
Some elements show handles in edit mode which can be moved by mouse dragging or keyboard commands.

tr.td: Fingering can be added to notes by dragging a fingering character from the fingering palette to a note head in the score. Fingerings are normal text which can be edited like any other text.

museScoreManual.page:
Frames Frames provide empty space outside of normal measures. They can also contain text or pictures. MuseScore has two kinds of frames:
horizontal
Horizontal frames break a system. The width is adjustable and the height equals the system height. Horizontal frames can be used to separate a coda.
vertical
Vertical frames provide empty space between or before systems. The height is adjustable and the width equals the system width. Vertical frames are used to place title, subtitle or composer. If you create a title, a vertical frame is placed before the first measure automatically if it is not there already.
Create a frame First select a measure. The command to insert a frame is found in the menu Create->Measures. The frame is inserted before the selected measure.
Delete a frame Select the frame and press <Del>.
Edit frame Double click the frame to enter edit mode. A handle appears which can be used to drag the size of the frame.
Title frame in edit mode:

Apoyatura Apoyatura Breve Apoyatura Larga Acciaccatura Appoggiatura Grace note
Una apoyatura breve o corta (Acciaccatura) se representa por una pequeña nota, generalmente corchea, rayada o tachada (rayita que cruza plica y corchete un poco inclinada). Se suele colocar justo antes de la nota principal, de tamaño normal, a la que va ligada. La apoyatura larga (Appoggiatura) no está tachada.
Puede crear una apoyatura arrastrando el símbolo de apotura de desde la paleta de notas hasta la nota principal.
Véase también (en inglés) en Wikipedia.

tr.td:
Key signatures are created or changed by dragging a key symbol from the key palette to a measure or existing key signature.
<F9> toggles the palettes window.
Change
Drag a key from the palette onto a key in the score. You can also drag a key from the score to another key on the score by using <Shift+leftMouseButton+Drag>.
Add
Drag a key from the palette onto an empty part of a measure. This creates a key at the beginning of the measure.
Remove
Select a key and press <Del>.

museScoreManual.page:
Lyrics
First enter notes
Select first note
Type <Ctrl+L> and enter lyrics text for first note
Type <space> at end of word to go next note
Type <-> at end of syllable to go to next note. The syllables are connected with a dash
<Shift+Space> moves to the previous note
<Ctrl+Space> enters a <space> into the lyrics text
<Ctrl+Minus> enters a <-> into the lyrics text
Syllables can be extended by an underline:
Entered with: "soul," ___"To" Esc.
Lyrics can be edited as normal text.
See also Text Chord names.

Measure Operations Insert Measure Delete Measure Pickup Measure
Insert Measures
First select a measure then press Ins to insert a new empty measure before the selected one.
Delete Measures
Complete measures can be deleted by first selecting them with Ctrl+Click. The measure is marked with a dotted line indicating that you selected a "piece of time". Press Shift+Click to extend the selection. Pressing Del removes the selected measures.
Properties
To edit the properties of a measure right click on an empty part of the measure and select Measure Properties....
Measure Duration
Normally the nominal and actual duration of a measure is identical. An upbeat can have a different actual duration.
Irregular
An "irregular" measure will not be counted. Normally an upbeat is not counted as a regular measure.
Repeat Count
If the measure is the end of a repeat you can define how often the repeat should be played.

museScoreManual.page:
Crear una nueva partitura desde cero
La entrada del menú <Partitura/Nueva> crea una nueva partitura. Primero es necesario agregar instrumentos a la nueva hoja, y luego puedes agregar compases vacíos
<I> ventana con el menu de instrumentos
<Ctrl+B> agrega compases vacíos
entonces el menu<Crear/Compás> puede ser usado para crear un número arbitrario de compases vacíos
Los siguientes pasos usualmente incluyen: elegir la clave, el tono, y el tempo.
Crear nueva partitura desde plantilla
<N> popups the <Template> menu. Select a template and click <OK>. This is the simplest way to create a new score. Note that template files are normal MuseScore files stored in the template folder.
<N> muestra el menú <Plantilla>. Selecciona una plantilla y haz click en <Ok>. Esta es la forma más simple de crear una nueva partitura. Nota que los archivos de plantilla son archivos MuseScore normales, guardados en el directorio template.
Crear una nueva partitura con el de manera guiada.

Ingresar Notas Acordes Ingresar Acordes Ingresar Pausas
Las notas son ingresadas en el modo <Note Edit>. Primero seleciona una nota o una pausa como posición inicial. Cuando ingresas notas siempre estás reemplazando notas o pausas existentes. Por eso la duración de un compás no cambia.
<N>ingresa al modo <Note Edit>.
<Escape> deja el modo <Note Edit>.
Luego de entrar al modo <Note Edit> debes seleccionar la duración de la nota que quieres ingresar seleccionando un valor de la paleta de notas o presionando:
<Alt+1>1/4 nota <Alt+2>1/8 nota
<Alt+3>1/16 nota <Alt+4>1/32 nota
<Alt+5>1/64 nota <Alt+6>1/1 nota
<Alt+7>1/2 nota
Las notas se ingresan presionando
<C D E F G A B>:
<Espacio> crea una pausa
<C D Espacio E>:
Las notas se agregan a los acordes presionando <Shift+NombeNota>
<C D Shift+F Shift+A E F>:
Los "Beams" son creados automáticamente
<Alt+1 C D Alt+2 E F G A>:

Palettes You can drag&drop palette symbols onto score elements.
Double clicking a palette symbol is equivalent to drag&droping this symbol to all selected score elements. For example you can easily put a tenuto on several notes at once:
select notes
double click on the tenuto symbol in the attributes palette

Play Mode MuseScore has an integrated sequencer and synthesizer to play your score.
By pressing the <Play> button you enter <Play> mode. In <Play> mode the following commands are available:
<Space>toggle stop/play
<Left> seek to previous chord
<Right> seek to next chord
<Ctrl+Left> seek to previous measure
<Ctrl+Right> seek to next measure
<Home>rewind to start of score
<F11>toggle show play panel
If you want to play instruments other than piano you have to change the MuseScore integrated SoundFont with a more capable one in the I/O tab of the Preferences menu.

Repeats The start and end of simple repeats can be defined by setting appropriate bar lines. In the last measure of a repeat you can set the property "Repeat Count" to define the number of played repeats.
See also: Volta for first and second endings

Slurs
select first note:
<S> creates a slur
in edit mode:
<Shift+Right> moves the slur
end to the next note:
<X> flips the slur direction:
<Escape> ends edit mode:
A slur can span several systems and pages. Slur start and end is anchored to a note/chord or rest. This means that if the notes move in a relayout, the slur moves to.
See also Ties, Edit Mode.

Tempo Play back tempo can be changed via the play panel or via tempo text in the score.
Play panel
Display the play panel: Display --> Play Panel (F11)
Change the Beats per Minute (bpm) using the Tempo (Tmp) slider
Tempo text
Select a note to indicate where the tempo text should be created
From the main menu: Create --> Text... --> Tempo... (Ctr+Alt+T)
Select the desired tempo text and make adjustments to text or BPM if necessary
Press OK to finish
Existing tempo text can be changed by double clicking the text to enter edit mode. Beats per minute (BPM) on existing tempo text can be adjusted by right clicking on the text and selecting "Tempo Properties..."
Note: Tempo text in the score will override a tempo setting in the play panel.

Text Editing Double click on text to enter edit mode:
In text edit mode the following commands are available:
<Ctrl+B> toggles bold face
<Ctrl+I> toggles italic
<Ctrl+U> toggles underline
<Up> start superscript or end subscript if in subscript mode
<Down> start subscript or end superscript if in superscript mode
move cursor: <Home> <End> <Left> <Right>
<Backspace> remove character to the left of the cursor
<Delete> remove character to the right of the cursor
<Return> start new line
<F2> Show text palette. The text palette can be used to enter special characters and symbols.
See also: Chord Names, Lyrics

Text Text elements are created from a Text Style. This style defines the initial properties of text.
Text properties:
font family
Name of the font such as "Times New Roman" or "Arial"
point size
the size of the font in points
italic, bold, underline
font properties
anchor
page, time, notehead, system, staff
alignment
horizontal: left, right, center; vertical: top, bottom, center
offset
an offset to the normal anchor position
offset type
mm, space, or percent of page size
Text types:
title, subtitle,
composer, poet
anchored to page
fingering
Fingerings are anchored to note heads.
lyrics
Lyrics are anchored to a time position.
chord names
Chord names are also anchored to a time position.

Ties
select first note:
<Shift+S> creates a tie:
When in note entry mode you can press <+> before entering the first note to create a tie to the next note.
See also Slurs.

Tuplets Triplets
To create a triplet first create a note with a duration of the whole triplet. Then select the note and press <Ctrl+3> to change it to a triplet. Similarly <Ctrl+5> changes the note to a quintuplet.
First select a note:
<Ctrl+3> creates a triplet:
which can be further edited

Undo/Redo MuseScore has unlimited undo/redo functions.
The standard shortcuts are:
<Ctrl+Z>Undo
<Ctrl+Shift+Z>Redo

Volta Volta brackets are used to mark different endings in a repeat:
Volta brackets can be place on the score by drag&droping from the lines palette.
The brackets can span more than one measure. Double click the volta to enter edit mode and then move the handles with:
<Shift+Right>one measure left
<Shift+Left>one measure right
This commands move the "logical" start or end of the volta which determine the bracketed measures. Other commands in edit mode also move the handles but do not change how the repeat is played.
If you move the handles, a dashed line from the logical position to the actual position is shown
Properties
Repeat List
This list determines which repeat the volta should be played. If the volta is played in more than one repeat all repeat numbers must be listed and separated by a comma (",").
Text
You can set an arbitrary volta text. Of course the text should correspond with the repeat list.

One-bar rests When an entire measure is devoid of notes, a full measure (semibreve) rest is used.
A one-bar rest can be created by marking a measure and pressing Del. All notes and rests on this measure are then replaced by a one-bar rest.

Crescendo Diminuendo Decrescendo Hairpins
Hairpins are line objects.
To create a hairpin first select a note to mark the start point.
H create a crescendo hairpin
Shift+H create a diminuendo hairpin (decrescendo)
Hairpins could also be created by dragging a hairpin symbol from the line palette to a note head.
H create a crescendo hairpin:
double click switch to edit mode:
Shift+right move end anchor:
right move end point:

Cross staff beaming
In piano scores it is common to use both staves (bass and treble clef) to write a musical phrase.
This can be entered in MuseScore as follows:
First enter all notes
in one staff:
Shift+Ctrl+Down moves the selected
note or chord to the next staff
See also Bar line for cross-staff bar lines (i.e. grand staff).

Tremolo
Tremolo is the rapid repetition of one note or a rapid alternation between two or more notes. It is indicated by strokes through the stems of the notes. If the tremolo is between two or more notes, the bars are drawn between them.
There are separate symbols for one note and two note tremoli in the tremolo palette.
In a two note tremolo every note has the value of the whole tremolo duration. To enter a tremolo with the duration of a half note (minum) first enter two normal quarter notes (quavers). After dragging a tremolo symbol to the first note the note values automatically double to half notes.
